title: 104_hr1114
content: AUTHORITY FOR 16- AND 17-YEAR-OLDS TO LOAD MATERIALS INTO SCRAP PAPER BALERS AND PAPER BOX COMPACTORS. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to allow 16- and 17-year-old employees to load materials into scrap paper balers and paper box compactors that are safe and cannot be operated while being loaded. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to allow 16- and 17-year-old employees to load materials into scrap paper balers and paper box compactors that meet safety standards set by the American National Standards Institute. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to allow 16- and 17-year-old employees to operate scrap paper balers and paper box compactors that meet safety standards certified by the Secretary to protect minors. The machines must have an on-off switch controlled by employees aged 18 or older. Employees aged 16 and 17 can operate scrap paper balers and paper box compactors if they meet safety standards certified by the Secretary. The machines must have an on-off switch controlled by employees aged 18 or older, and a notice must be posted confirming the safety standards are met. The Secretary will publish a standard for scrap paper balers and paper box compactors certified by the American National Standards Institute. Employees under 18 cannot operate or unload the machines, while 16- and 17-year-olds can only load them. The Secretary will publish a standard for scrap paper balers and paper box compactors certified by the American National Standards Institute to protect the safety of minors. Employers must report any injuries to employees under 18 resulting from contact with the machines during loading, operation, or unloading. The Secretary will use reports of injuries or fatalities of employees under 18 from contact with scrap paper balers or paper box compactors to assess the safety impact of the implemented standards. The reports of injuries or fatalities from contact with paper box compactors will be used by the Secretary to evaluate the safety impact of the implemented standards. The reports will include details such as employer and employee information, incident date, and place of employment. The reports of injuries or fatalities from paper box compactors must include details like employer and employee information, incident date, injury description, and equipment details. Reports must be submitted to the Secretary within 10 days of the incident. The reports of injuries or fatalities involving scrap paper balers or paper box compactors must be submitted to the Secretary within 10 days of the incident. The Secretary cannot solely rely on these reports to determine violations of child labor laws and must conduct an investigation before making any determinations. The Secretary must investigate reports of oppressive child labor violations before making any determinations. Reporting requirements expire 2 years after enactment. SEC. 2 amends the Fair Labor Standards Act by including section 13(c)(5) in the civil money penalty provision. SEC. 3 clarifies that the exemption for apprentices and student learners in the Code of Federal Regulations is not affected.
